1.review: If you're an R-Type fan or shmup fan this is a must have. It's basically exceeded my expectations in almost every way and I just can't put it down. It's not a game for the faint of heart or for those easily frustrated. This game will tear you apart but it's so rewarding to find a path forward and to find solutions as it's a shmup but each screen almost plays more like a puzzle that can only be passed with the tools available to you. I haven't played a shmup in years and it took me about 12 hours to beat the game finally on normal and there's 2 difficulties and a few unplayed branching stages I have yet to find. I'm going to get well more than my 40 dollars worth. The soundtrack and most of the graphics are great, the level and enemy placement is designed tight and with a lot of thought and care. The game runs great on my pc and I really don't have a lot of complaints. There's a few bugs Granzella has acknowledged and a stage or two where the graphics are a bit lacking compared to others. There's a few muddy textures here and there but these are small complaints. Buy it. If you're even here you're probably interested and know what you're getting into. R-Type is back and it's fantastic. Helluva job Granzella!

2.review: MASTERPIECE. I skipped Final so can't compare the two but when comparing this to Delta the gameplay is just as exciting. Love the level design, boss design, and enemy layout. Some truly tricky sections and tough enemy bottlenecks really make you want to improve. Feels really good once you finally figure out how to ace those tougher sections. Love the music and graphical effects along with the multitude of ship choices and weapons. It's truly beautiful and runs perfectly smooth @ 1440p and 144fps. Honestly I wasn't excepting this game to be so good after reading so many complaints. Have to say those complaints are wrong IMO (except for those having performance issues) Don't know what else to say about the game except F2 is now a go to favorite of mine.

3.review: Some of the best gameplay of the series but the atmosphere and spectacle are not quite up to the very high standard of the classic games.

4.review: I have been a big fan of R-Type games and the Shootemup genre for over 3 decades. This latest game is very good, it plays smooth and its very responsive. The only thing I am disappointed with is the screen modes and resolutions available. I am running the game in 2560x1440 and fills my Ultra Wide Screen. Message to the Devs, please add proper 21:9 Ultra Wide Screen resolutions like 3440x1440 & 3840x1600, and I'm sure there are some Super Ultra Wide Screen monitor uses that would appreciate some modes for their monitors. I would love to be able to play R-Type Final 2 in 3840x1600.

6.review: This review will be updated in time as the game is updated. I want to recommend this game, as I have been a fan of R-Type since the first few games over 30 years ago now. But right now the game has issues, issues that can hopefully be fixed! Right now the game is buggy, has lag issues during key moments of fights, and has menu glitches that make it impossible to interact with the game if you alt tab out and tab back in. Currently, I have not gotten to any of the final paths of the game (It has branching paths beginning with level 6 depending on a choice you make at the end of level 5, similar to the first Final). However, the reason for this has not been because the game is too hard or I'm bad at it or any complaints with the levels themselves. When I reached level 5 the first time, I died to the final boss on it, alt-tabbed out to check a discord message, and when I came back the game wouldn't do anything. I could not hit continue, I could not select a fighter, nothing. Controller and keyboard become completely unresponsive, no matter what button I pushed I just got nothing or an error sound from the game. So I quit it, and retried. Same thing happened when I alt-tabbed again. The menus are also buggy when looking through the bydo labs and the other gallery sections, not properly responding to directional inputs, leaving your input in a spot it wasn't upon exiting out of a menu, etc. Just now I played again, got through stage 6.2, and the game crashed for the third time today trying to load stage 7.2. tl;dr Game is good, but currently I cannot recommend it due to constant bugs and crashes hampering the experience, among other minor nuisances that add up to tedium across the experience. Even barring all that, as much as I love R-Type, this has less content than R-Type Final on the PS2 and costs $40 plus a $20 season pass for more levels, all while having far less ships than its predecessor. The graphics are phenomenal, but the content is a bit lacking right now, I hope to see more in the future that will change this to a recommended, because more content is still being added, both paid and free. Biggest things that need to be fixed are menu errors, input issues, and the crashes. tl;dr, again: If you love R-Type, get it If you just like schmups, wait for a sale.

7.review: I love me some R-Type and this game seriously nails it. After believing R-Type Final on the PS2 really would be the final R-Type, and then hearing about Irem going under, I didn't think I'd ever see this game. I wasn't holding out hope. This game was a day 1 purchase for me and I don't regret it in the slightest. The intro sequence gave me those excited goosebumps I only get on the best of occasions. The soundtrack has me hooked and I've barely scratched the surface of this game. I can't wait to dig in further. But based on what I've seen so far, I would recommend this game to fans of the series in a heartbeat. Is it perfect? I dunno, probably not. I'll admit I'm being a total fanboy over here. But I sincerely think the team behind this game have done an excellent job and have stayed faithful to series. This feels exactly like the kind of R-Type game I would want here and now.

11.review: Love Letter for Shooter and R Type Fans I've been playing lots of shooter games till now, especially R Type series. from original title (1-3) and R Type Final on PS2 back before. And since that time, I've been waiting until I find very good quality shooter games again. And I'm very happy my waiting comes to end when R Type Final 2 released on Steam several days ago. And when I'm only on the early stage of this game with very minimum playtime, I'm absolutely can say positive things about the game: - good graphic and style. Reminded me a lot of R Type Final graphic style, but better and smoother this time. The effect of weapon retain same vibe with R Type 3, even on the early stage you will fight giant mecha same as R Type 3. what a nostalgic scene - good pace of enemies wave. and it gets tougher on higher difficulty stage with limited space on screen to manuever your ship - Good variety and design of ships. What is a shooter without good looking and cool ships to choose? This is the reason why I played R Type since back then. And this time, it comes with good range of ships to choose. And I think they still keep the original ships, and similar unit like albatros and cerberus from previous R Type games - decent customization options for your unit. so far, Im quite satisfied to get opportunity to choose color for lots of ship parts, even add visible decal on your ship What I think Developer need to improve for further patch update: - some of menus had difficulty to navigate (either with keyboard or controller). Especially in gallery and several options menu. I find on several occasion its like stuck and kind of difficult to get back to previous menu Overall this is a really good shooter game, and dare I say its a love letter for shooter and R Type fans. So go on, do yourself a favor and try the game ASAP :)

12.review: Not good, but good enough. The first R-Type Final had 101 ships that could be obtained through playing the game. This iteration uses a bizarre in-game currency system and has entire ship development paths locked behind a password for kickstarter backers. I think it's kind of sad that fans of the first will miss out on ships they had access to previously. Also, the addition of an adaptive difficulty baffles me. Why pick normal difficulty if it's going to get harder? Why pick bydo or r-typer difficulty if it's going to relent when the player hits a rough patch? I don't know who asked for that feature to be added, but the game doesn't seem to benefit from it in any way unless they plan on removing the difficulty selection altogether. My opinion, not gospel. R-Type Final 2 manages to be prettier than Final 1, but I feel the level design leaves a lot to be desired. To that end, if the player finds themselves using only 1 out of 99 available ships because the stage layout renders the others almost useless, there must be an issue with the level design. All that said, it's not bad, nor unplayable. I just find myself unable to recommend it to anyone but fans of the series. I couldn't recommend it to all fans of the shmup genre as shmups tend to come in many incarnations -this title is a sort of niche within a niche. I would not recommend this game to anyone who isn't a fan of R-Type. Fans of R-Type who have not played R-Type Final will probably get a kick out it. To anyone who has played R-Type Final, skip it. There's nothing new to see here.

24.review: As an original backer on Kickstarter 2 years ago, I would say the wait was worth it and It's a fantastic shmup. Anyone familiar with the R-Type franchise knows what they're getting into for the most part here. It's not like the Danmakus and Gradius-like shmups that require super fast reflexes, but it's more about strategy, atmosphere, and the story-telling as told through the level design. I remember still being in high school when I pre-ordered R-Type Final 1 for PS2 from Gamestop and I was so excited to discover all the levels and unlock all the ships. A lot of those levels back then were a little too long, so it's nice to see the levels in this sequel shortened, similar to the very original R-Types in a way. However, I do miss the bits of quotes and story that were in Final 1 to add a little more depth and intrigue into the gameplay. The graphics are gorgeous and everything runs smoothly on a decent machine. Performance-wise, this is what R-Type FInal 1 should have been as I did go back to playing it last year on my PS2 and found everything so sluggish. You basically have to emulate it on PCSX2 to get it to feel and play more like Final 2. Being such a fan of the series, I did pre-order the high end collector's edition for PS4 from the NIS America website mainly for the awesome R9-A metal earth model. It was nice to receive it early and try out the game a couple days before release, but I can definitively say you must get it on Steam if you have a machine capable of running it smoothly 60-144fps with no hiccups. At least your chances of dying due slight frame rate stutters will be lessened lol. At the backed price of $30, to get the game and all the DLC that was planned is a fantastic price. At the price of $65ish for the complete package and digital copies of the OST and art book is still pretty good... 11 main stages and (I think) 6 planned DLC stages? 99 ships to unlock. I mean, I bought Dariusburst Chronicles with all the DLC when it was on sale at some point, and have only played it a handful of times, finding everything to be just a little too generic. You can always wait for a sale too, but it's definitely a must buy for anyone who's an R-Type fan or even a fan of shmups.

25.review: This plays like R-Type and feels like the R-Types of old. It could have done with a little more polish (stage three is underwhelming, especially in the graphics department) but it has branching stages, dozens of ships to unlock and you are bound to find some to suit your play style. Above all, it is fun. Frustratingly so, perhaps. It's great to play a new old-style shmup in 2021. Image Fight III next, please.

26.review: (Background: I was introduced to the series with Super way back when, loved it, and played and loved Delta and Final 1; I played all 3 of those [i]again[/i] the day before Final 2's release to give myself a solid reminder of how things evolved and what Final 2 was about to be tacked onto the end of.) For those who have forgotten, R-Type Final 1 came out for the PS2 in 2003. Yes, 18 years ago. However, I believe very firmly that Final 2 is a beautiful ode to that which Irem had established R-Type, in general, had evolved into by the time Final 1 had come out, in a much sleeker and more pleasing aesthetic than Final 1 offered (my  I hated Final 1's menu aesthetic and sounds, and Final 2's are great). In essence, I'd argue Granzella did [i]not[/i] drop the ball on how it [i]feels[/i] to play an R-Type game - I think they got the overall feel correct. As [i]for[/i] feel, not only should I mention that the ships seem to control fine, but difficulty is part of feel as well, and yeah, R-Type has historically been on the hard side; Final 2 is merely no different in that regard and thus also hits [i]that[/i] nail on the head - "R-Type" and "particularly easy" just [i]don't[/i] traditionally go in the same sentence together, so you simply [i]can't[/i] go into Final 2 expecting the game to just keel over for you. Effort is required to beat this game. For what it's worth, I felt that Practice difficulty here feels to me about as hard overall as Baby (the equivalent difficulty) did on Final 1. The stage design also seems pretty spot-on for general obstacle placement and difficulty of navigation; it is good modernization of the notions of what Irem themselves previously put us through in Delta and Final 1. I will also give HUGE praise to stage 6 of Final 2 for the wheel cycles being [i]amazing[/i] and giving you extra opportunities for entrance/exit that you might not have thought you'd have: some previous games - R-Type III being the worst offender by far - had situations where Irem was [i]VERY[/i] unfair with cycles, automatic doors, walls, or other hair-pulling stage design elements; Final 2 never throws any wholly unfair stage design stuff at you, and I see that as fantastic. I think the main takeaways here should be:  We should count ourselves [i]considerably[/i] lucky that after [i]18 years[/i] we even [i]have[/i] a new mainline R-Type game [i]at all[/i], regardless of who made it.  We should be happy that Granzella has managed to get it as right as they [i]have[/i] - I agree with their cheesy tagline that Final 2 is "the best R-Type we can make now."  I recommend that any fan of R-Type in general play Final 2; I feel that any actually-reasonable human being familiar with the series won't be disappointed.

28.review: I was a bit wary of the switch to 3D graphics and the Unreal Engine, as one of the things I loved about R-Type was the excellent bitmap graphics, but they have really made it work here. The weird bio-mechanical Bydo aesthetic is captured perfectly, the levels themselves make great use of movement and depth, and most importantly, the reflective lasers glow powerfully against the dark corridors. The modern engine also allows for super high frame rates, which is a revelation in a game as twitchy as this.

32.review: After playing this game for a while, I can say without issue that it's a solid shoot'em up and a good R-Type title. Its original levels follow a more simplistic design compared to R-Type Delta and Final, and are overall more linear and, "videogame-y" rather than having the feel of a 3D adventure like the previous games, but they're an overall fun experience, with bosses that are in my opinion very creative and very, very fun to fight, the highlight of most levels. The difficulty of the game varies a lot between the five settings, allowing for a more relaxing and easy experience for less-skilled player (such as myself), to incredibly challenging at the higher difficulties, providing an experience suitable to all players. The weakest part of the game is without a doubt the graphics - although the game can be truly gorgeous to look at in certain moments (especially in regards to the ship and the effects of their weapons), many stages present occasional low quality textures if not models, with stage 3.0 being the most egregious example. It can (and 3.0 straight up will) look jarring, but at least for me it doesn't take away from the overall experience of the game. I haven't played long enough to explore the depth of the ship variety, but for what I've seen they did a stellar job in that regard. The various vehicles maintain the same feel as their R-Type Final counterparts, their models and particle effects are beautiful and the customization, while not flawless, allows for some very fun tinkering with the look of your vehicles. Unlocking the ships is way different than in Final, where you were required X minutes of playtime with another specific vehicle for most of them; here, you have to buy them with currency obtained by beating levels, which means you are no longer forced to fly ships you may not like for long periods of time, but you're also not rewarded for failure anymore - whereas in Final you could die over and over and over in one section while still making progress towards the unlocks, here you'll need to reach and defeat the boss to earn the currency... But on the plus side, you can progress even just by playing your favorite ship this time around. Overall for what I've played, this game is a solid 7.5/10 - despite its flaws it's a very pleasant and fun experience, and I plan to keep going to see all this game has to offer. And while more content will indeed be welcome (not that this game is lacking in that department, quite the opposite), I'd love to see some graphical tweaks in the future to make the overall aesthetic of the game become truly beautiful to look at.

33.review: My downthumb for this game is based mostly on it's $40 price tag. It's a good game in its own rite, however it has some flaws. At first the game looks great, but as the game goes on you start to notice it kind of looks like a 2001 original XBOX game. The texture quality and polygon count takes a major dive in certain levels and its a serious shame (Look at this late game boss: https://i.imgur.com/FLYZVEq.png). On top of that the music is entirely forgettable. They did a good job of making the first few levels and especially the player ships and selection screens look really good but that's it. You have 99 ships or so to unlock but there's only about 7 levels to play (10 with DLC). No graphics quality options, buggy controller support... Sometimes even the gameplay is frustrating due to cheapshot enemy attacks and dated movement mechanics. You can use an analogue stick but its still 8 way movement with buttons that shift you through 4 speed levels.... come on now, was this made for arcades? No? Then design the game with analogue control. I realize that's not traditional for R-Type, but still, lets get with the times. I'd wait for a sale unless you've beat the previous R-Type games and really want it. Otherwise, I would say you're better off catching up on previous entries in the series for now. Theres so many great shmups on steam that you can pick up for less then $10. Go buy like 5 or 10 of those instead. In the future people may look at this game fondly, but right now it's freakin expensive for what it is.

34.review: In the sense that people wanted another R-Type Final, you're pretty much getting that; 2 plays much like the previous, with all its ups and downs. The slightly touched-up functions of the old Wave Cannons you know and love are positive for the most part; Andromalius gets a particularly welcome upgrade from this, as the shockwave continues to inflict damage for a split-second to catch another minor Bydo or two as they advance. Barrier Wave goes faster and further than before, although it's still around as bad as it's always been offensively so don't lose that Balmung. Dose builds up a bit faster - a lot faster in certain specific areas (the bio-goop walls you have to destroy in some regions counts each individual little block as a 'hit'). There's a little something in Stage 1 regarding how early you can build it. Speed is reset to 2 when you die which is slightly annoying but minor. The ship models are beautifully detailed, a real joy to look at. The weapons have this odd style to their coloration (the original Photon-Belts in particular) but it doesn't look bad, kinda grows on you after a while. The sound... sounds about right? It sounds like R-Type Final for the most part. Not gonna win any awards there but it's the same old atmospheric elevator death muzak you remember. The effects don't seem out of place, though at the same time because of it we're reminded of the series' age. Two minor points against though: - Couple of the stages feel particularly short, 4 in particular (boss was fun though). [Edit: Stage 7.1 makes up for this: very long, and -near breathtaking] - The stages are also prone to very similar-feeling tunnel sections, so I'm hoping the resurrected previous-game stages will help there as Delta and Leo in particular were usually great in that respect. We'll see if Fire Cask Factory retains its infamy. (Edit: OKAY YEAH IT DID THAT WAS BRILLIANT) Game's not fully optimized for all systems(hopefully that's a 'yet'); I get no problems other than the system running a little hotter than the requirements would suggest, but some folks on the forums speak of slight stutter at the start of a stage (nothing compared to what the console players are apparently experiencing though). Not really surprising for... almost any game launch nowadays though when we think about it, but "everybody does it" does not make anybody doing it better. If you didn't like the original, you're never going to like this. If you loved the original, absolutely give this one a shot. Just remember, it's been over fifteen years for most people; we're the ones who've changed.

38.review: It's gorgeous and a worthy successor to Irem's long line of shooters. Plays solidly even on my 3-year-old, Intel I5 / midrange Geforce GTX gaming laptop. As with most any R-Type game better know what you're getting into -- lots of getting blowed up while you learn every new pitfall that's been laid for you. This one isn't for folks who aren't willing to fail -- and fail a LOT -- before getting good. The one thing I would change is adding an option to the settings to let the player select their own default ship speed. It's not a deal-breaker, just something that would be real nice to have.

39.review: Fun! Feels just like R-Type Final but better. I really like it. HD 16:9, good level design and ques from previous games. I do miss some of the music from R-Type Final but the music does seem better overall. I enjoyed playing solo and taking turns as it's even more visually pleasing to watch than before. Minor personal nit pick is some brightly lit bullets blend in too easily around bright areas making the bullets harder to notice in time than I remember especially compared to the older games. 42.review: It is amazing to see R-Type return once again, and better than ever, loved it! Proud to see this game becoming a reality ever since from the April 2019 teaser tbh. [h1]Recommended to try even if you're new to R-Type?[/h1] [b]Definitely yes![/b] The game has more extended difficulties, and has been made much easier for newcomers to get in to and enjoy the game casually. For veterans, this too is also a good pace of new things to try, as in higher difficulties, the game can get really punishing for your mistakes. Starting off again from a checkpoint is never an easy thing, but with [i]dynamic difficulty[/i], it makes you possible to pick up back from a checkpoint as they optimized it slightly convenient for you to pick up where you died off, even if your power ups are  ( you lose all power ups if yo get shot ) As someone that plays a lot of predecessor of R-Type games, Final 2 is an amazing take, felt almost like a concept combination of R-Type Delta (with their good stage designs), and R-Type Final 1 on the PS2 (good introduction to many usable fighters). So this is considered the state of the art of R-Type games, with a lot of good things to take in. The part that made it better with this PC port? You can game more than 60fps, and this is surprisingly something I have not really witnessed in other Shoot Em Up games in my life. This is certainly pleasing to look at, as I have a working 144hz monitor, and it works wonders. Resolution in game can go up beyond 1080p if you have a very beefy PC.

46.review: -Launch Day Review- As a kickstarter and a giant fan of R-Type and Shmups i was very eager to boot up the game and play this game. I've been waiting for years for another game that takes what previous R-Type games did but better and.....well. It's more R-Type but i think a good explanation is in order. First up, it feels and plays just like Delta/Final in a good way. Ship with a unforgiving hitbox, force core at the front. Speed up and down buttons to adjust movement. This is 100% a R-Type game, with plenty of ships to use and unlock. The problem is that it's trying to be the early R-Type games while also trying to be like Delta/Final, but it's drawing on too much from the former than the latter. Considering that this game was marketed like it was going to be more Delta/Final than R-Type 1/2/3 it's somewhat misleading. Two big examples is the OST and the Level design. There's too much energy in the music for the most part and it seems to have some pacing issues (perhaps a technical issue?). It's not bad music mind you, but it feels like it would had fit a more retro-themed or hard-core game. Now the Level design....OH BOY. This...this is a doozy for me. It doesn't make good use of it's '3D space'. It feels like you're always travelling on a line. "But R-Type games have you always travelling on a line." True for the early games but again, Delta and Final did things to compensate. Interesting Rotations of the background, moving the scenery about, water effects and it had enemies come in and out of the scene in cool ways. Final 2 meanwhile only uses it for the most part to rotate into another 'line'. It feels like a waste of the UT4 engine. In addition, some of the checkpoints and enemy placement are completely unforgiving. There's one point on stage 4 that is literal cancer if you don't have a weapon for it prior. And if you die at that point of the stage you have to do it without access to any weapon other than your wave cannon and if your wave cannon can't deal with what are basically solid objects then you're done, restart the game because it would be faster to get back to that area instead of trying to futilely throw yourself into what is essentially several walls made of angry flesh. Visuals are also mixed bag. On one hand you can get some really nice shots here and there with sweeping views of space, planets in the background with objects in-between to create a lovely setting. On the other you have objects close up that look like melted chocolate. I think something may be broke with the LoD on them. At least the game runs silky smooth (For me at least). All in all. I really wish there was a 'neutral' button for a review. The game is enjoyable enough with solid gameplay and tons of unlockables. You'll generally have a good time if you're a Shmup fan but it does seem to lack a bit of it's predecessors soul.

48.review: i can't believe it was like 17 years ago since R-type Final on PS2. Being called "Final" i never expected to see another R-type come to life. And yet, here it is. Was it worth this 17 years? OH ABSOLUTELY! Is it perfect? No, there is plenty of stuff that could have improved the game, like different ships (we have the very same ones in Final I), or add a new mechanic to the gameplay, or using more crazy camera angles. In the core, it is the same R-type Final with new maps and graphics. But at the end of the day, i have played 8+ hours in the day of relase and loving every single second of it. Honestly I couldn't be happier to be playing R-type again like when i was a kid. I'm pretty sure i will sink 100+ hours in this, and i really hope that people buy and love this game like i do, because it would be nice to see another R-type game again at some point in the future. This is a 10/10 for me, worth every $.

62.review: Would I recommend this game? Yes, but. I backed the initial crowd funding campaign and paid ~£25; for that price I'd say it's pretty fair, but it seems the price on steam is currently ~£35 which is a little steep, and nearly £60 for a version of the game with some pointless DLC thrown in. I completed the game on the easiest difficulty setting in 3 hours, so there is certainly lots of replay value with all the unlockable ships, 3 higher difficulty settings and multiple routes/end stages to complete just like the original R-Type Final had. When you consider that, the current £35 price tag isn't too bad- it is a very pretty game but really that's all it offers largely, it doesn't bring anything new to the table at all besides a few new enemies and updated graphics, and a re-hash of previous stages/bosses. This could ( should.. ) have been a HD remake of R-Type Final and it would actually be a better game I dare say as a result. I'd happily pay to get a HD remake of that game and R-Type Delta, this game is 'fun enough' but it seems to have an identity crisis, not knowing if it's a partial remake or trying to be it's own thing, and not doing a great job of either- good enough to enjoy, but certainly didn't blow my mind either. I would certainly wait until it goes on sale, or the price drops etc etc- in the mean time, go and replay the original games and remind yourself of how great they were, and still are; sprites ftw!

71.review: I believe this game had a pretty troubled development (including three separate crowdfunding campaigns), but I'm glad we got it in the end. R-Type Final 1 is one of my favorite shoot-em-ups so I'm glad to see just another R-Type in general. All the ships are lovingly rendered, though the stages come off as a bit samey and simplistic (only played up to stage 4 as of this review). There's a lot of nice little touches. The bosses are pretty creative, and riff on other bosses in the series which is nice. Final 2 has... differences I'm not sure about. I like that the stages are shorter and you get a ton of credits by only playing a couple hours, and I LOVE that you don't need to play ships for a certain amount of time, you just grind the three currencies to buy them. Which... is its own thing, but at least I get to choose what ship I want while I grind. On the other hand, I feel like the game is a lot stingier when it comes to checkpoints; not in the amount, but that you'll restart and have to navigate the stage without a Force for a while. At least it means I have to get good. I don't think it's a perfect game, but I wasn't expecting it to be. I wanted another R-Type, and another Final at that, and I think this is a great fulfillment of that vision. I can't wait to see the stage variants and all the little secrets Granzella's put in.
